results.headline: Yes, She Has a Sweet Tooth, but She’s a Major Carnivore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood and Chocolate

results.summary_short: Interspecies mating is always a challenge, particularly when one species likes to eat the other.

results.headline: Sometimes Pulp Fiction Emphasizes Pulp Over Fiction

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smokin' Aces

results.summary_short: “Smokin’ Aces” is a Viagra suppository for compulsive action fetishists and a movie that may not only be dumb in itself, but also the cause of dumbness in others.

results.headline: A Rocky Mountain Road to Happily Ever After

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Catch and Release

results.summary_short: The romantic comedy “Catch and Release” is refreshing for what it doesn’t have. There is no whiny, spoiled golden girl and no baring of claws.

results.headline: Love Means Always Having to Say You’re Sorry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breaking and Entering

results.summary_short: “Breaking and Entering” climaxes in a welter of apologies. Everyone in London, it seems, has cause for remorse and for my part I regret that I lost count of the number of times the words “I’m sorry” were uttered on screen.

results.headline: The Heartbreak of Cheap Labor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of China Blue

results.summary_short: “China Blue” reveals more than we may care to know about the provenance of our most beloved item of clothing, blue jeans.

results.headline: Fantasy and Farce From Far, Far Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of From Other Worlds

results.summary_short: Aliens offer a cure for earthling ennui in “From Other Worlds,” a limp sci-fi comedy with fewer laughs than a meeting of Abductees Anonymous.

results.headline: A Loud Outcry Against Genocide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Screamers

results.summary_short: Part rockumentary, part howl of outrage, “Screamers” is an invigorating and articulate film.

results.headline: Our Father, the Nazi Zealot: A Family Grapples With Its Burdens and Blind Spots
results.display_title: 2 oder 3 Dinge, die ich von ihm weiß

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 oder 3 Dinge, die ich von ihm weiß

results.summary_short: The new documentary “2 or 3 Things I Know About Him” offers an unusually matter-of-fact picture of the private and public effects of ordinary evil.

results.headline: A Maleficent Obsession? Could Be More Than Heaven Allows

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shockproof

results.summary_short: While “Shockproof” will inspire more groans than gasps, it’s essential viewing for fans of filmmakers Samuel Fuller and Douglas Sirk.

results.headline: Easy Does It, the Next Stop Is a Killer. No, It Really Is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hitcher

results.summary_short: Like the same-titled 1986 cult favorite, this remake is a crash-and-burn action horror with intellectual pretensions.

results.headline: Grace Notes: To Be Young and in Paris in 1968

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Regular Lovers

results.summary_short: This tender portrait of late-1960s French youth stars Louis Garrel as François, a 20-year-old Parisian struggling through the fires of revolutionary promise and its smoldering remains.

results.headline: Nino and His Oh-So-Present Memories of Underdevelopment

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mafioso

results.summary_short: Alberto Lattuada’s incomparable, half-forgotten 1962 crime comedy-travelogue is at once a giddy mixture of farce, satire and opera buffa.

results.headline: A Place Where Hope Dies, and a Boy Who Escapes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Italian

results.summary_short: A dark fairy tale from Russia, “The Italian” pulls you into a richly atmospheric, persuasively inhabited world teeming with foundlings and pathos.

results.headline: A Father and a Son Tell Their Own Tales of Love and Loss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Goodtimeskid

results.summary_short: Azazel Jacobs’s unexpectedly beguiling romantic comedy, “The GoodTimesKid,” finds poetry in wordless scenes of observation.

results.headline: Rejected by Society, a Woman Struggles to Carry On

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dam Street

results.summary_short: Like any number of Chinese films that make the festival rounds, “Dam Street” offers a portrait of alienation in a post-Mao world as believable as it is grim, grim, grim.

results.headline: The Long Lens of Obsession and Mad Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alone with Her

results.summary_short: Writer and director Eric Nicholas’s latest film, “Alone With Her,” is a voyeuristic thriller that is fiendishly assured yet ultimately less than the sum of its parts.

results.headline: Polyester and Power at Play for a Mogul and His India

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guru

results.summary_short: You might think it would be difficult to fashion an entertaining account of the life of a polyester manufacturer. But director Mani Ratnam has done so with “Guru.”

results.headline: Reporters Tail a Killer Croc

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Primeval

results.summary_short: "Primeval" is one of several recent movies to bill itself as "inspired by true events." So was this review, though in both cases "inspired" may be too strong a word.

results.headline: After a Struggle to Escape Comes an Effort to Adjust

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of God Grew Tired of Us

results.summary_short: "God Grew Tired of Us" is a sober, uplifting documentary that follows the resettlement in the United States of three young men uprooted as children by the civil war in Sudan.

results.headline: Gun-Slinging Cowboys in Colorful Thailand

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tears of the Black Tiger

results.summary_short: There may be crazier movies than this Thai cowboy melodrama of betrayal and forbidden love, but I can't think of one that is quite so mad about its own craziness.
